intro: Drudeophytum kelloggii, commonly known as Kellogg's ghostflower, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its small, pale yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in rocky, arid environments, showcasing its adaptation to harsh, dry conditions. Its leaves are narrow and succulent, helping it retain moisture in its native habitat. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
